artefact.overview: You need a licence from the Home Office if you possess or sell category 1 scheduled substances
artefact.licence_short_description: Licence from the Home Office to possess or sell category 1 scheduled substances.
artefact.licence_overview:
If you possess or sell category 1 scheduled substances, you must obtain a licence from the [Home Office.](http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/ "Home Office"){:rel="external"}

 Your licence will be valid for three years from issue, or for longer if you can show every three years that conditions are being met, and will state the operation(s) and substance(s) for which it is valid.

##Conditions

You may supply those substances only to people who hold a licence and have signed a customer declaration which shows their intended use of the substances. You must obtain a copy of this declaration which must be in a set format. You must stamp and date a copy of the declaration and certify that it is a true copy.

If you work as a pharmacist or veterinarian, you may apply to the Home Office for a special licence, which will be valid only for the use of the scheduled substances within the scope of your official duties. Special licences are for an unlimited duration, but may be revoked or suspended.

If you sell category 2 scheduled substances, you must register with the Secretary of State, providing the address of the premises where the substances are manufactured or traded, and if you are a pharmacist or veterinarian, you may apply for special registration.

If you sell either category 1 or 2 scheduled substances, you must appoint an officer to be responsible for ensuring that the trade is conducted properly. You must notify the Home Office of the officer's name and contact details.

Exceptions apply to certain category 2 substances.

Licences and registration may be subject to fees and conditions.

The Home Office will consider your competence and integrity when deciding your licence application.

You must ensure that all transactions leading to the sale of the substance are properly documented. Documents (eg cargo manifests, invoices) must include enough information to identify:

* the name of the scheduled substance
* the amount and weight of the scheduled substance and in the case of a mixture or natural product, the percentage of the scheduled substance it contains
* the name and address of the supplier, consignee, distributor and any other operator involved

The documentation and records must be kept for at least three years and be made available for inspection by an authorised person.

The above requirements do not apply to transactions involving category 2 scheduled substances where the quantities involved in a period of one year do not exceed the specified threshold.

You must ensure that labels showing the names of the substances are attached to category 1 or 2 scheduled substances before they are supplied.

You must notify the Director General of the Serious Organised Crime Agency immediately of any circumstances where you suspect that scheduled substances might be used for the illegal manufacture of drugs.

You must provide the Home Office with a summary of your transactions involving scheduled substances every six months.

You must allow any authorised person to enter your premises and inspect any scheduled substances or documents relating to your dealings with scheduled substances.

##Fines and penalties

Your licence may be revoked or suspended if the Home Office believe you no longer meet the competency and integrity criteria or you have failed to comply with licence conditions.

If you possess or sell scheduled substances without a licence, without being registered or if you fail to appoint a responsible officer you may commit an offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

%If you fail to comply with documentation, labelling and notification requirements you may commit an offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to three months or both.%
